economic_context.details: Multiple debt disputes: Jean owed Jean Francois money and offered 'une hugette' in payment which was refused; Jean owed Diaz Francois 10 francs which he needed to repay for house. Jean worked as laboureur, forestier (forest keeper for bois de la Magdelaine), bread seller, and coffin maker. Witnesses described Jean as poor. Economic reversals were major theme: Jean allegedly threatened to reduce wealthy neighbors to poverty, and these threats allegedly came true for Demenge Gillat and George Colas Bergier.

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete trial record with detailed witness testimony, torture confession, and retraction. Trial shows classic pattern: long-standing reputation (up to 18 years), multiple witnesses reporting quarrels followed by harm, Jean's prophetic threats that allegedly came true, and his failure to seek legal redress for being called witch. Notably Jean confessed under torture after being racked 3 times, naming 8 accomplices at sabbat including his own wife, but later retracted all accusations against others while maintaining his own guilt. Death sentence issued 12 October 1592. Economic themes prominent: debt disputes, predictions of poverty that allegedly came true, contrast between rich and poor. Mother also suspected. Multiple instances where Jean allegedly knew things supernaturally (death of Demenge Ban before being told). Trial demonstrates significant economic anxieties and social tensions in the community.
